text: [MUSIC]

Ted Williams said, “the hardest thing to
do in a sport is hit a baseball.”
[MUSIC]
I think he was right.
[MUSIC]

These guys make it look easy… but hitting
a major league fastball pushes the brain and

body to their very limits. How do these guys do it?
Are they superhuman genetic freaks? Do they
see the world in Matrix-like bullet time?

"Now batting, number 42, Joe 'The Hustle'
Hanson"

One of the first things they teach you in
Little League is to “keep your eye on the

ball.” But that’s easier said than done.
I can barely see that thing.

A pitcher starts 60 feet, 6 inches away from
home plate, and actually releases the ball

several feet closer. From that distance, a
90 mph fastball is only in the air for about
400 milliseconds.
That’s not a lot of time.

We can perform simple reaction tasks in less
than 400 milliseconds, but hitting a baseball
is a little more complicated.

Hitters aren’t just reacting to a pitch,
they’re trying to make a big stick arrive

at the same time and location as a tiny moving
sphere. They only have a 9 millisecond window

to make contact, just a half inch margin of
error.

To make things worse, the hitter has one big
disadvantage. They’re living in the past.
We all are.

Because of the time it take our sensory information
to be synchronized and processed, our consciousness

lags 80-100 milliseconds behind actual events.
By the time the brain registers there’s

a pitch on the way, it’s already a quarter
of the way to the plate.

Considering the average major league swing
takes about 160 milliseconds, that only leaves

140 milliseconds for the brain to think “SWING!”,
send a signal to the motor cortex, and down

to the arm. It takes longer than that just
to blink.

[MUSIC]
[CROWDCHEERING]

Baseball great Yogi Berra allegedly once said,
“You can’t think and hit at the same time.”

He was right. There’s just not enough time
to sense, decide, and act on a pitch. Baseball
players almost have to think without thinking.

The first phase begins before the pitcher
even starts to move. How many outs are there, where

are the runners, what does this pitcher like
to throw when there's two strikes? The context

of the game can help narrow down the possibilities,
give the hitter a sort of ballpark estimate.

The pitcher winds up, the batter begins to
move, and then things go subconscious.

Batters go into every pitch as if they’re
swinging, their bodies have to get a head

start. Their eyes are locked on the exact
location and distance of the pitcher’s release

point, there’s no time to focus or move
the eyes into position.

To hit the strike zone with any pitch, a pitcher
has to release the ball inside a cone just

2 degrees wide and within half a millisecond
of their target.

Batters are able to analyze tiny differences in the angle
of release of the ball, to determine if it
has any chance of crossing the plate.

From this point on, the batter just has to
figure out when the ball will cross the plate,
and at what height. Easy, right?

With data like velocity, rotation, parabolic
motion… a computer could easily calculate

the time of intercept. Unfortunately, we’re
not robots, we've got to use sensory clues
instead.

When something moves closer to us, its angular
size increases. The faster that shadow grows

on our retina, the faster it’s moving towards
us.

And because we have two eyes, each gets a
slightly different view of that ball's growing

shadow, and our brains are able to put together
those tiny differences and translate it into
the ball’s flight path.

The batter’s eyes and head remain locked
on the pitch until it’s about 6 feet from

the plate, constantly adjusting their predictions
along the way. If everything goes just right…

What’s crazy is nearly all of this action
bypasses the batter’s conscious brain! How

do they see all this when my brain only sees
a blur?

The center of our retina contains the highest
density of photoreceptors in the eye, this

is why we see best when we look right at something.
But thanks to genetics, some people have have

more cells in the middle of their retinas
than others.

A higher density of cones in a given area
means more resolution.

In eye exams, the average major league player
tests at 20/13 vision, with 80% below 20/15,

and some even approach 20/8, the theoretical
limit of human vision.

In the 1990’s, Los Angeles Dodgers scouts
were able to predict which minor league players

would succeed in the majors based solely on
how low they performed on eye exams.

A baseball’s red laces can give different
pitches a tell-tale signature in flight.

A 2-seam fastball’ can look like two red
stripes based on its backwards rotation, a

slider’s lateral movement can paint a red
dot on one side.

Hitters, thanks to their experience and their
expert vision, are able to pick up on these
patterns in flight.

What distinguishes an expert hitter from…
well, someone like me, is their ability to

process information earlier, faster, and more
efficiently. They have some physical attributes

that make them well-suited to cranking the long
ball to the cheap seats, but they’ve also

trained their brains to be specialized fast-motion
processing devices.

It’s just as much about software as hardware…
maybe even more.

I clearly need an upgrade.
Stay curious.
